title: 104_hr4162
content: The Act titled "Continued Participation Pension Act of 1996" allows certain individuals to continue participating in defined benefit plans under the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974. The Continued Participation Pension Act of 1996 allows qualified beneficiaries to continue accruing benefits in a defined benefit plan after a qualifying event. This ensures that participants do not incur a break in service with the employer, maintaining the nonforfeitability of their accrued benefits. The Continued Participation Pension Act of 1996 allows qualified beneficiaries to continue accruing benefits in a defined benefit plan after a qualifying event. The period of continued participation is considered service with the employer, and earnings and forfeitures are not included in determining liabilities. The Continued Participation Pension Act of 1996 allows qualified beneficiaries to continue accruing benefits in a defined benefit plan after a qualifying event. The period of participation extends until the participant reaches normal retirement age, the employer stops providing the plan, or benefits cease due to failure to make contributions. Qualified beneficiaries electing continued participation are liable for contributions. The Continued Participation Pension Act of 1996 allows qualified beneficiaries to continue accruing benefits in a defined benefit plan after a qualifying event. Qualified beneficiaries electing continued participation are liable for funding any obligation of the plan to provide benefits, including employer and employee contributions. Benefit accruals from voluntary employee contributions are only provided if available prior to the qualifying event. The Continued Participation Pension Act of 1996 allows qualified beneficiaries to continue accruing benefits in a defined benefit plan after a qualifying event. Benefit accruals from voluntary employee contributions are provided only if available prior to the qualifying event. Contributions by the qualified beneficiary during continued participation are limited to 102 percent of the applicable contribution for the period and can be made in monthly installments. The Continued Participation Pension Act of 1996 allows qualified beneficiaries to continue accruing benefits in a defined benefit plan after a qualifying event. Contributions by the qualified beneficiary during continued participation are limited to 102 percent of the applicable contribution for the period and can be made in monthly installments. The election period for continued participation must begin before benefits accrual would cease and last for at least 90 days. The Continued Participation Pension Act of 1996 allows qualified beneficiaries to continue accruing benefits in a defined benefit plan after a qualifying event for at least 90 days. Any election of continued participation by a qualified beneficiary includes other beneficiaries who would cease to be beneficiaries due to the qualifying event. The act does not apply to defined benefit plans with fewer than 20 employees. Definitions include the applicable contribution and qualified beneficiary. The Continued Participation Pension Act of 1996 allows qualified beneficiaries to continue accruing benefits in a defined benefit plan after a qualifying event. A qualified beneficiary is any beneficiary under the plan on the day before the qualifying event, including the participant in certain cases. A qualifying event includes termination or reduction of hours of employment, or the death of the participant within seven years of normal retirement age. The Continued Participation Pension Act of 1996 applies to plan years starting on or after July 1, 1996. For defined benefit plans under collective bargaining agreements ratified before the Act's enactment, the effective date is the termination of agreements or January 1, 2000.
